SorcerAR

Trailers for Personal Experiences and Attractions

Beta test Attractions before you construct them

Augmented Reality up until now has been an overused novelty act. The AR application landscape is cluttered with clunky User Experiences and Marker based apps that have little to no replay value.

Mixed Reality for the win

Mixed Reality is the middle ground between Augmented Reality, and Virtual Reality. It allows for users to experience simulated/virtual worlds by walking through them, and seeing through them. We believe that a mixed reality approach is the best approach for at least the next 5 - 10 years. We are also fans of things that work. By preferring hardware sensors to Computer Vision (which is computationally expensive, and prone to catastrophic failure), we have built a system that not only works, but is also a natural and truly magical experience.

Characters that travel with you, and remember you

Entertainment and interactive media are premier experiences for Mixed Reality, especially when the focus is on Storytelling. Artificial Intelligence has the potential to add life to virtual environments, through background characters, wildlife, and even through digital actors that interact directly with human participants. Our interactive characters can travel with players as personal companions, moving throughout their devices and bringing their memories and experiences with them.

GolfBid

GolfBid

Inspiration?

The requirements and the skill set with regards to the GolfNow challenge was a perfect match for our team skills. The technology was familiar to us and we felt that we could push the limits and create a good product that innovates using GolfNow's current technology.

We reviewed the available tech of the hackathon and felt that the GolfNow purchase integration with the televised steaming purchases would be a great combination.

Target?

The target user would be described as someone on a tight budget that loves to play golf and can find a great deal doing so.

GolfNow loses a lot of inventory and there is much more value in having a golfer at the course than it going unsold. Our software allows for the golfer to pick the price and if they get it, better for golfer, golf course owners and GolfNow.

The Spark?

The way we have gone about thinking about the system. We have created 2 layers on top of the GolfNow API. The 1ste being the abstracted API layer that handles all the bidding and the Interface that goes on the set top boxes. This code can easily be migrated and used on a variety of systems, like Mobile Apps, Desktop Apps.
USense

USense is a mobile app that is designed to improve the Universal Studios experience for those visually impaired and hard-of-hearing. We designed our app to be used by voice command to help our users interact with ease.

USense also helps those who may be deaf or partially deaf by including closed captioning on all text in the app. Many of the UI elements are also designed to use high contrasting colors.

With the help of beacon technology, we can buzz the phone to notify users when they are approaching an attraction or point of interest and provide information through text-to-speeh and closed captioning.

Our app uses the following technologies:

  • Text to speech
  • Voice recognition
  • Beacons

I assisted with the implementation of the design for the demo. I programmed data to be received by the app to respond to proximity of the user to a beacon. I also worked with all the team members in the brain storming sessions to help solidify our idea.
Wanduh

To bring immersive, engaging experiences to the guests at Universal Studios our team sought to bring new, innovative technology to enhance the magic wands of Olivanders. Our Alternate Reality Game (ARG) presents guests with an invisible war against the Dementors who frequently invade Diagon Alley and its surrounding lands. Guests are encouraged to use their wands to vanquish the Dementors across the park to collect points and earn incentives such as Express Passes and coupons.

When a wand wielder flicks their wand, any Dementors nearby are instantly vanquished. This is visible in the companion application which places Dementors based on wait time data to coax guests to low traffic areas. If a guest is in a queue the mobile application can interact with park installations to create an immersive, dramatic experience using context and location aware special effects. For our proof of concept our team has implemented the Philips Hue lights in concert with the mobile app to give the wand a pronounced effect on stage.

Malignant Monsters (Team 6)

This is an interactive game that connects attendees of Halloween Horror Nights to the monsters in the park and engages a broader audience with the Legendary Truth experience.

By placing beacons on a large number of scare-actors at Halloween Horror Nights, we enable guests to experience a new level of interaction with monsters and murderers.

Guests with the mobile application installed will receive collectible cards when they come close to scare-actors. Each card highlights a character from Halloween Horror Nights' past or present or a bit of lore from Legendary Truth.

In addition, some scare-actors will "infect" a portion of the guests who pass by. The mobile app communicates with a PixMob light bracelet, which allows guests to see when they have become infected. Scare-actors can be instructed to pay extra attention to guests whose bracelets pulse with a blood-red glow. This adds an immediate, simple reason for guests to care about and invest energy into the game and creates a memorable experience for guests "lucky" enough to get infected. For extra fun, infected guests can find a healing scare-actor to cure their digital affliction.

Finally, each collectible card can be flipped to reveal a Scruples-style question themed to the event. The questions are designed to make guests think and discuss, creating entertainment for any time spent waiting for a haunted house or other attraction.

Many elements of this design can be adjusted for use in other events and areas of the parks.

Perspective

Perspective grew out of the pain involved in adding interactive content to online videos with services like Adways. We thought, why not automate this process with contextually aware technologies? Solutions like Google Goggles have made strides in this space, but failed to gain adoption because they were too processor intensive for a good user experience. Advances in mobile tech and IoT now allow other approaches. We built an initial proof of concept that showed great promise so we evolved the idea into an immersive mobile app for guests to engage at events or theme parks. This Meerkat-styled app allows users to capture their surroundings while learning about the story behind the scenes. Interactive hotspots automatically appear over people and places in view, driving deeper engagement in the experience. Theme park attractions can now entertain guests with fresh content while they wait in queues and not bear the cost of recreating physical space.

Getting the Perspective solution to work involved a mashup of several web services and IoT technologies. We use BLE and IP light markers to uniquely identify the people and places captured through the camera. We use the OpenCV processing engine to isolate PixMob wristbands and Hue lights in the scene and modulate these in Morse-Code-style patterns. These are then linked with meta-data in a backend data store triggered by clickable hotspots overlaid on the screen. Pointing the app at a person might show their Twitter feed floating above them while pointing it at an attraction could bring up the full story behind it. The best part is that these feeds can be broadcasted or recorded for consumption anytime and anywhere in the world.

A special gift, just for you

Originally, the design was to provide an app that would help reduce the time a guest has to stand in line. But the reality is that most people standing in line do not have any device at hand. No loose items are allowed on the most popular rides. Someone is usually sitting nearby, holding the bags and looking at a phone.

Waiting has benefits

Why not offer that person a coffee? or an ice cream? or a discount on a gift item. Or, maybe a suggestion for where to go for lunch?

What's nearby?

Using geofences and beacons together with a smartphone, the guest can receive notices from nearby merchants. By extension, the same "make the wait worthwhile" approach can be used to send passing guests special offers.

The technology can limit the number and type of notices so the guest is not inundated. Similarly, the offers can be targeted to the type of guest or the group. By incorporating a redemption code, it's possible to track purchases and refine the offers, making them more relevant to the guest.

Hufflepuff

We have chosen to take on the Universal Studios Parks & Resorts Technology Challenge, which is to design an enhanced entertainment experience for the visually impaired inside the park.

We have designed a platform for both information and entertainment, utilizing beacons that trigger either informative or entertaining audio samples inside the park. These can be welcome guests to new areas of the park, highlight useful locations such information, help, and restrooms, as well as guide guests to attractions that feature accessibility options for the visually impaired. They can also be entertaining for both visually impaired guests and their friends and family, telling a story through multiple beacons in a 3D environment and featuring sound effects and dialog between multiple characters. Sequential hotspots could tell a story of the adventures of a character through each themed area of the park.

These audio 'hotspots' would only be triggered by guests that have enabled this feature on the Universal FL app. After enabling the feature on the app, they would be given a brief audio tutorial instructing them on the key sound to listen for throughout the park, synchronized with a phone vibration. The vibration would be enabled even if the App is in the background.

VR Enabled

This is the opportunity to make a missed experience a VR Enabled experience.

Backstory: The idea behind this project is the solution to an unfortunate experience where a member was kicked off the hollywood rip ride rocket roller coster for being too big. While celebrating their 9th anniversary at Halloween Horror Nights, Patrick and Alysha where next in line to get on the ride. Upon entering the seat to be secured, Patrick was told he was too big for the ride and would have to wait for his wife on the side. Once reunited, Alysha was so excited about her experience but Patrick was mad about his and this ruined the rest of their celebration.

This is only one example of many of people who come to the park expecting so much but instead leave with heartbreak and missed experiences due to many reasons and ailments. With the deployment of VR ride replicas we can now help create and cherish these experiences.

Target User: People that are unable to ride rides or want to experience a ride from a different perspective. Individuals with heart conditions, pregnant women, young children, elderly, visually impaired, and the physically impaired.

Key Features: Ability to experience a ride with your friends and family members despite your current physical condition. With virtual reality tools, and audio tools we're able to cater to a wide range of audience.

MythOS

Created by: Bernard Marger, Michelle Pieler, Nick Tardif, Matthew Gates, Matthew Bigham

Submitted for the Technology and Entertainment categories

MythOS is a scalable, lightweight, and unobtrusive platform designed for immersive content delivery. Through the use of Radius Networks Bluetooth beacons, individual users can be tracked as they move throughout the park, allowing for the creation of a unique experience involving personalized proximity­-based audio events and custom environmental behaviors with the integration of Spark Core technology. User tracking is used in conjunction with audio and environmental effects in order to provide more personalization and a greater level of interaction with the guest as they explore more points of interest within the parks, letting the guest become a part of the Universal Mythos.

AssistedPerception

StoryLine

Inspired by the wall of buttons in the Transformers queue, we saw an opportunity to invite queuing guests to have agency within the world, instead of merely passively absorbing a looping video feed or staring at the same prop for minutes on end. The second inspiration was to break our guests out of their coccoons they wrap themselves in when they resort to poking at their smartphone. They shouldn't be playing with the toys they brought with them after paying loads of money for a vacation; the park should provide them toys to play with, instead!

However, we want to take this play one step farther than just personal, simple joy. We want the guest to contribute to a fun little mini-narrative, aided by their immediate neighbors and everyone else in the same "queue room."

Since you'll be spending a lot of time with strangers--even sharing a ride vehicle--a shared group accomplishment helps everyone become a little less "strange" to each other.

Why Jurassic Park? Universal property, Everyone loves dinosaurs, No deep knowledge of lore required to recognize characters, Mixture of technical & organic aesthetics, New movie(s?) coming out

Security Breach Example -Play around with idea of security failure by having guests help in what turns out to be a minor matter -Three stage narrative progression, three stations --Big security status lights indicate current state ---Flash when it’s time for group activity ---Changes from red to green to indicate progression --1. Need help locating and pointing camera at some “activity” in shrubbery near guest line (live footage and gags) --2. Discover lack of camera control due to “some punk” messing with exposed security station ---Panel has tons of gizmos, but only a few are functionally wired ---Panel shows desired changes and group presses/toggles /twists indicated gear ---Show photo on screen of random person from your room group who was blamed as “culprit” --3. “Something” actually broke through, but don’t worry--it’s just a little lizard ---Find and point out projection that scurries across wall and behind decorations --Light goes all green, fun lightshow, happy chime

Callback examples -That rustling you saw in line early in queue is what you need to seek out later on in Security Room -When ride track deviates, new audio indicates it was probably due to someone pressing that switch you were asked not to touch -Photograph of the “culprit” person from your general neighbor group as “Employee of the Month” at end of ride, timed with some sort of personal tracker

Universal Studios Trivia

Our team decided to take a simplistic approach to solve 2 problems: improve guests experience while waiting inline, and also engage guests to explore and interact with other guests.

We developed the prototype with the idea of being simply integrated in the current universal studios app.

We created a trivia game, where which set of questions is composed of 5 questions. The questions will always be related to the context you are currently in. For example, you are at dumbledore’s office waiting line for the harry potter ride? The trivia question will be related to Dumbledore character.

After you complete a set of questions, you earn a badge. Guests can collect badges, which will motivate them to explore new areas, visit the park at different seasons, share them to social networks, or check their ranking on a leaderboard.

U-Discover

Universal has an on going theme of the magic or wonder that is all around us just out of sight. That slight magical reality switch makes the impossible real just around next turn. Whether it's magical ability in the Wizarding World of Harry Potter, mutant DNA in Marvel, or technology in Jurassic Park. U-Discover uses that immersive experience with game-based missions to rethink the the traditional line system.

First let's examine the functions a queue performs:

  1. It spaces out boarding of the ride in a manner that balances arrival time with passenger throughput.
  2. It generates a sense of fairness regarding boarding time within the audience.
  3. It provides initial immersive experience to initiate suspension of disbelief.
  4. It provides time for the transmission of safety information.

All of four of these needs and more can be accomplished by tasks, while incentivizing the user.

A user enters the park and receives a message in the Universal App asking if they'd like to have an interactive experience. If they select opt in, then their smartphone (or a wearable for minors/adults without smartphones) opens functionality.

Upon reaching the entrance to a ride with U-Discover features, a full screen notification alert pops up in the universal app offering the opportunity to participate in a challenge composed of several tasks.

Once the last task in the series is is completed a key is sent via cloud to the gate station that allows entry.

This provides the following possible functions:

  1. Timing and number of tasks can be determined based on observed and predictive metrics. This can allow on the fly traffic control.
  2. Users have a sense of progress and accomplishment obtained by transit and completion of tasks.
  3. The sense of skill and prowess provides an alternative sense of reason for boarding times.
  4. Tasks can be included that mimic safety needs with motion tracking devices such as leap motion and kinect. This could include; pulling the bar down, maintaining a clearance envelope, and other ride specific safety regulations. This can ensure reception of the information by call and response, rather than
  5. Users are encouraged to interact with the immersive world and utilize more regions of the park than they otherwise might visit.
  6. Users are available to make purchases of food, merchandise and use restroom facilities during that wait time rather than being stuck in one location.
  7. Tasks and challenges can be modified to provide different experiences over time allowing for novelty and updating while using the same equipment
  8. For Harry potter specific rides, Integration with Pottermore will allow story customization by house and the allocation of points to houses, based on tasks completed.

There is a lot for our team to celebrate. Technologically, we are most proud of our variable switching iBeacon system. We use an iphone and an Intel Edison as variable TX/RX iBeacons to act as a cue. This could be adapted to provide logic gates with a number of different sensor input. Conceptually, The use of gaming as a a queue system represents a radical shift that allows a deeper level of guest engagement by leveraging both existing and yet to come technology. Aesthetically, Being able to tell a story within a story adds depth and flavor to an experience we already cherish. Yet, the biggest accomplishment for us all is the team. We arrived individually, certain we'd be leaving by the afternoon because we wouldn't have the skill to continue. Today, thanks to our varied abilities, we've created an idea.

Vignettes

Vignettes are location based, interactive, AR experiences scattered around the park to enhance the theming. Imagine if people in Diagon Alley could see Harry Potter and his friends zoom around the sky and play Quiddach. Or people visiting Islands of Adventure could watch Spiderman face-off with Doctor Octupus in the streets. Because these shows are all digital, they can be large scale, and dynamic and interactive. The app will notify people when they are inside an AR hotspot to see the action. Users can team up with friends and family to earn more points and unlock all of the challenges around the park. Points can be redeemed for prizes and concessions at participating Universal Studios shops.

BookNow - Tee Times

We have created mobile web-app prototype designed to reduce the amount Tee time slots that go unsold in a given day. We have done this by focusing on reducing the restrictions getting in the way of golfers who want golf, and integrating additional contextual and social media data in order to further change the model from one where users look for tee times, to one where the right tee times do then.

By expanding the golf-booking experience with social media platforms like facebook, we are also creating opportunities to expand the sales of tee times outside of current customers.

We've taken the current golfnow api and added in extra layers for pushing out tweets, retrieving tweets by location, sending and receiving SMS, collecting weather information in the future, sending marketing emails.

We believe this platform will enable GolfNow to expand into a world of social golf, where transactions are fluid and your growing user base are delighted

We were inspired by the challenge of finding ways to decrease unused inventory. We were told that 70 percent of Tee times are booked within 48hrs and 40% of them were booked same day. We wanted to create an app that integrates with various social channels and new data sources to make booking times and registrations quicker and easier to do.

Line Animation

The average person spends around 72 hours a year waiting in line, and when visiting an amusement park this problem is even worse. Anyone with an android smartphone will be able to use our services, at no extra cost to the participants. If we can deliver an experience that captivates the waiting audiences imagination and reward them for it, who wouldn't want to be a part of it? The list of materials for participants will be Google Cardboard and Radius Networks bluetooth beacons.

Augmented Reality combined with stereoscopic vision using the Google Cardboard gives you an immersive and fun experience. Digital characters based on the specific ride the user is in queue for are revealed by AR markers placed all over the particular area prepping the user for the ride.

Can be expanded to AR games played by groups of people or individuals waiting in line.

Spiderman Snapshot

Waiting in line for theme park rides has traditionally been a passive experience, in spite of the fact that the majority of a guest's time can be spent there. Spiderman Snapshot is an idea for a multi-station interactive experience where guests use their hands to interact with the Spiderman world while they wait in line.

With Spiderman Snapshot, we wanted to design something that people could walk right up to and start playing with little or no instruction, and for as little or as long as they liked. We utilized a natural user interface to invite people of all ages and backgrounds to step into the Spiderman universe and share an experience with each other capturing pictures of villains for the front page of the Daily Bugle.

In the experience, guests make a picture framing pose using their hands. When showing this pose, guests have three seconds to frame their shot before a picture is taken. The goal of the experience is to capture the nefarious acts of villains on the loose as they dash across the city's landscape.

Spiderman Snapshot is designed to be one of multiple experience stations set up through out the queue for the Spiderman ride at Universal's Islands of Adventure. Our goal when designing the application was to create something that could be used by anyone and could fit into existing models of queues and rides today.

Key Features:

  • Use your hands to take pictures of super villains
  • Find secret photo ops in the environment
  • See virtual polaroids of shots you've taken

ExpressFit

Our app measures how much a user has walked inside the park and allows them to earn a single use express pass for a specific ride. By suggesting places to walk that will help them earn ,we can create engagement in lower used areas of the park, along with suggesting restaurants and shops to visit while the user is earning their express pass.

Outside the park, the app incentivizes users to stay engaged with universal and active through discounted express passes after a certain amount of days meeting the specified goal.

Harry Potter’s Wizard Duel: Defense Against the Dark Arts

The forces of darkness are assembling against Hogwarts. Dumbledore is gone, and it is up to the students to learn how to defend themselves against the Dark Arts. Now it is your time to join Dumbledore’s Army and test your dueling skills.

We have built a prototype of an augmented-reality platform that allows guests to engage in wizard duels against one another, earning points for themselves and their House. Our goal is to maximize the Harry Potter experience. Queue lines are long and space for physical entertainment is at a premium. Harry Potter Wizard Duel revolutionizes theme park entertainment with augmented reality. By maximizing guest engagement through an inexpensive, flexible platform, you encourage repeat visits as the game evolves. Additionally, the app presents a new revenue stream for Universal Studios, as it can be expanded to include in-app purchases like new stories and spells, and merchandise tie-ins, like advanced wands and themed clothing.

Our technology is built on the Unity Game Engine using Bluetooth communication via iOS GameKit and Vuforia Augmented Reality. Initially, we used the cube wand tips you see for rapid prototyping, but the final version will use computer vision to detect the tips of licensed wands.

Augmented reality provides massive expansion potential for Universal. The game could be expanded to include a massively multi-player co-op mode where wizards team up to battle Dementors threatening to take over Hogwarts. Crowds can gather to watch top wizards battle it out on giant projection screens using Microsoft Kinect technology. Location awareness can enable the presentation of appropriate stories in different themed areas. Guests in Marvel Super Hero Island might be able to fight Dr. Doom using Thor's hammer...

Jurassic Snap

The idea for this game came from our shared interest in Jurassic Park and the idea of making the queuing experience more interesting. Jurassic Snap is a mobile VR game where the goal is to take pictures of dinosaurs in the environment. We are very interested in mobile VR and are working with Wearality using their prototype headset. We are mostly targeting people who line up for the Jurassic Park ride and don't enjoy just standing around while they wait in line. The biggest idea for this app is providing an experience that enhances the ride you are waiting on by exposing you to more of the same and providing an experience to be immersed while in the queue.
Universal Quest

Universal Quest

Universal Quest is an extension of the Official Universal app which focuses on creating adventure between rides and during queue times.

This mixed media extension is capable of maximizing guest engagement, increase retail traffic, generate and maintain higher attendance levels.

Our group is comprised of heavily RPG inspired game designers and developers. We drew upon these elements when creating this interactive extension of the Official Universal app.

The core idea is to motivate users to explore the park in new ways by providing the adventurer(s) quests to complete! Rewards range from character experience points to rare accessories for their avatar.

The player created avatar starts as a level 1 adventurer with a basic set of accessories. Upon completing quests ranging from scavenger hunts to experiencing attractions, one could earn XP to level up their character or rare accessories used for customizing their avatar.

This apps plans to accomplish the following:

1, Crowd control by incentivising visits to less populated park areas.

  1. Generate and maintain interest to return.
  2. Allow for unique ways to experience the parks.
  3. Establish a social forum to showcase your avatar.
  4. Provide entertainment in queues with minigames and quests.

The Minigames

  1. Scanvenger Hunts
  2. Trivia Quizzes
  3. Ride Adventures

Each minigame integrates story of the park areas into their flavor text.

Scavenger Hunt

Using beacons and Radius software we can use the beacons to activate and track quests as well as trigger completed finds. The Pixmob light watch can also be utilized to display to the player when they are moving closer to the objective based on the frequency of flashes of light.

Trivia Quizzes

Utilizing the geolocation of the user, the trivia mini game will pull questions relative to the area of the park you are in, further introducing story elements of an area to the user.

Ride Adventures

The goal with Ride Adventures is to reward the player with XP, accessories, or even store coupons and promotions for doing what they came here to do: experience attractions.

There are also ambitions to be able to print your avatar with 3DME!

Let the adventure live on with Universal Quest!

League of Adventure

Our target user is any guest looking for a little more depth and engagement in between attractions. With the many static set pieces and features in the park, we felt there were opportunities to create miniature interactions unified by a central thread of story. Our goal was to think of a game that would engage guests on a level that made the story about them (joining a larger organization to catalogue the mysteries of the Islands) while giving players a reason to explore some of the perhaps less visited or often passed-by areas of the park. We felt that the possibility of making guests' own mobile devices the platforms for VR experiences would be a convenient way to allow players to see and interact with characters that are difficult to achieve with effects outside of attractions.

Ideally, this game would engage individuals but also be a fun activity for families to work on together, or compete against each other. League of Adventure missions, being assigned to guests based on an individual profile, might direct different guests to different areas of the park to help distribute guest flow.

We felt that the Port of Entry's theme has potential to be expanded into something that could tie each of the islands together - we were inspired by the themed mannequins in the Trader Market store to suggest an existing cast of characters homed to that area, who would be unique to IoA and could behave independent of the park's other licensed properties, while having a broad connection to each of them (explorers and researchers.) We're proud of visually communicating what we feel is a fun concept, and showing an example of how temporarily immersive VR experiences could help bring to life otherwise static park features (the Spinosaurus statue.)
